natural problem: Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$
natural solution: From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\

&= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes matrix :: "real^2^2" 
assumes h0 : "matrix = 
    (\<chi> i. if i = 1 then 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 1/50 else 7/50) else 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50))"
shows  "matrix = 
    (\<chi> i. if i = 1 then 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 1/50 else 7/50) else 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50))"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem 
fixes matrix :: "real^2^2" 
assumes h0 : "matrix = 
    (\<chi> i. if i = 1 then 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 1/50 else 7/50) else 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50))"
shows  "matrix = 
    (\<chi> i. if i = 1 then 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 1/50 else 7/50) else 
    (\<chi> j. if j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
A 2x2 matrix is defined as follows:

If i = 1 and j = 1, then the element at position (i, j) is 1/50.
If i = 1 and j ≠ 1, then the element at position (i, j) is 7/50.
If i ≠ 1 and j = 1, then the element at position (i, j) is 7/50.
If i ≠ 1 and j ≠ 1, then the element at position (i, j) is 49/50.

Verify that the matrix is defined correctly according to these conditions.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2"
and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = matrix [1, 7]"
and h1 : "\<forall> w. w \<cdot> (v /\<^sub>R (v \<bullet> v)) = matrix_mult P w"
shows  "P = matrix [[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2"
and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = matrix [1, 7]"
and h1 : "\<forall> w. w \<cdot> (v /\<^sub>R (v \<bullet> v)) = matrix_mult P w"
shows  "P = matrix [[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a vector $v = [1, 7]$ and a projection matrix $P$ such that for any vector $w$, the dot product of $w$ and $v / ||v||^2$ is equal to the matrix multiplication of $P$ and $w$. What is the matrix $P$? The final answer is the matrix $P = [[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]]$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes vector :: "real^2" and matrix :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "vector = vec (1, 7)"
and h1 : "matrix = (1/50, 7/50, 7/50, 49/50)"
shows  "projection matrix vector = matrix"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes vector :: "real^2" and matrix :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "vector = vec (1, 7)"
and h1 : "matrix = (1/50, 7/50, 7/50, 49/50)"
shows  "projection matrix vector = matrix"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a vector with components (1, 7) and a matrix with components (1/50, 7/50, 7/50, 49/50), find the projection of the vector onto the matrix. The final answer is the matrix itself.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix [ [1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50] ]"
and h1 : "B = matrix [ [1], [7] ]"
and h2 : "A *v B = B"
shows  "A = matrix [ [1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50] ]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix [ [1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50] ]"
and h1 : "B = matrix [ [1], [7] ]"
and h2 : "A *v B = B"
shows  "A = matrix [ [1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50] ]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If a 2x2 matrix A is defined as A = [[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]] and a 2x1 matrix B is defined as B = [[1], [7]], and the product of A and B is equal to B, then verify if A is equal to [[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]].

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "P = (outer v v) / (v \<bullet> v)"
shows  "P = matrix ([[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]])"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "P = (outer v v) / (v \<bullet> v)"
shows  "P = matrix ([[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a vector $v = [1, 7]$, find the projection matrix $P$ which is defined as the outer product of $v$ with itself divided by the dot product of $v$ with itself. The final result is $P = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{50} & \frac{7}{50} \\ \frac{7}{50} & \frac{49}{50} \end{bmatrix}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P *v x = (v \<bullet> x / (v \<bullet> v)) *s v"
shows  "P = matrix [[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]]"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P *v x = (v \<bullet> x / (v \<bullet> v)) *s v"
shows  "P = matrix [[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a vector $v = [1, 7]$ and a projection matrix $P$ such that $Pv = \frac{v \cdot x}{v \cdot v}v$ for all $x$, find the matrix $P$. The final answer is $P = [[\frac{1}{50}, \frac{7}{50}], [\frac{7}{50}, \frac{49}{50}]]$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M :: "real^2^2" and v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "M = (1/50, 7/50; 7/50, 49/50)"
and h1 : "v = (1, 7)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. ((M *v x) = (proj x v))"
shows  "M = (1/50, 7/50; 7/50, 49/50)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes M :: "real^2^2" and v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "M = (1/50, 7/50; 7/50, 49/50)"
and h1 : "v = (1, 7)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. ((M *v x) = (proj x v))"
shows  "M = (1/50, 7/50; 7/50, 49/50)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix $M$ with entries $(1/50, 7/50; 7/50, 49/50)$ and a vector $v$ with entries $(1, 7)$, show that for all vectors $x$, the matrix multiplication $M*v$ equals the projection of $x$ on $v$. Confirm that $M$ is indeed $(1/50, 7/50; 7/50, 49/50)$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "P = ((1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R) * (outer v v)"
shows  "P = matrix([[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]])"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "P = ((1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R) * (outer v v)"
shows  "P = matrix([[1/50, 7/50], [7/50, 49/50]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a vector $v = [1, 7]$, calculate the projection matrix $P$ such that $P = \frac{1}{v \cdot v} \times v \otimes v$. The final answer is $P = [[\frac{1}{50}, \frac{7}{50}], [\frac{7}{50}, \frac{49}{50}]]$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v w :: "real ^2" and P :: "real ^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "P = (\<chi> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1/50 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 7/50 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50)"
and h2 : "\<forall> w. w - P *v w = 0"
shows  "P = (\<chi> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1/50 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 7/50 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v w :: "real ^2" and P :: "real ^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [1, 7]"
and h1 : "P = (\<chi> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1/50 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 7/50 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50)"
and h2 : "\<forall> w. w - P *v w = 0"
shows  "P = (\<chi> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1/50 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 7/50 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 7/50 else 49/50)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a vector $v = [1, 7]$ and a matrix $P$ with elements $P_{11} = \frac{1}{50}, P_{12} = P_{21} = \frac{7}{50}, P_{22} = \frac{49}{50}$. If for all vectors $w$, the equation $w - P \cdot v \cdot w = 0$ holds, then confirm that the matrix $P$ indeed has elements $P_{11} = \frac{1}{50}, P_{12} = P_{21} = \frac{7}{50}, P_{22} = \frac{49}{50}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "P = (1/50, 7/50, 7/50, 49/50)"
shows  "projecting onto vector (1, 7) = P"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{x + 7y}{50} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{x + 7y}{50} \\ \frac{7x + 49y}{50} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/50 & 7/50 \\ 7/50 & 49/50 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "P = (1/50, 7/50, 7/50, 49/50)"
shows  "projecting onto vector (1, 7) = P"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the projection matrix for the vector (1, 7). The final answer is the matrix (1/50, 7/50, 7/50, 49/50).
